content.user_title: Monitor UniFi network infrastructure and diagnose issues
content.value_statement: Managing UniFi network infrastructure requires checking multiple sites, tracking device status, and diagnosing performance issues. This skill provides AI-powered tools to monitor site health, analyze device performance, and generate diagnostics for faster troubleshooting.
actual_capabilities: List all configured UniFi network sites
Get comprehensive health status for any site
List all devices within a site with status
Retrieve detailed device statistics (CPU, memory, uptime)
Compare health metrics across multiple sites
limitations: Requires an existing UniFi network with MCP server access
Cannot make configuration changes to network devices
Does not provide real-time alerting or notifications
Read-only monitoring - no device onboarding or provisioning

use_cases.title: Routine Infrastructure Health Checks
use_cases.description: Monitor all sites and devices to identify offline hardware, performance degradation, or connectivity problems before users report issues.

use_cases.title: Troubleshoot User Connectivity Issues
use_cases.description: Diagnose why a specific user or location has network problems by checking device status and performance metrics.

use_cases.title: Multi-Site Network Comparison
use_cases.description: Compare health and performance across all client sites to identify patterns and prioritize maintenance work.

prompt_templates.title: Check All Site Health
prompt_templates.scenario: Get overview of all network sites
prompt_templates.prompt: List all my UniFi sites and show their health status. Identify any sites with issues.

prompt_templates.title: Find Offline Devices
prompt_templates.scenario: Identify devices that are not responding
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all devices in my network that are currently offline or unreachable.

prompt_templates.title: Analyze Device Performance
prompt_templates.prompt: Get device statistics for all access points. Highlight any with CPU usage above 70% or memory usage above 80%.

prompt_templates.title: Generate Diagnostic Report
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a comprehensive network diagnostic report for my main site. Include device status, performance metrics, and any identified issues.

output_examples.input: Check all site health and show me which devices have problems
output: ‚Ä¢ Branch Office: Major Issues (3 devices offline, high latency)
‚Ä¢ AP-Branch-01: High CPU (85%), packet loss detected

best_practices: Start with site health checks before diving into individual device details
Correlate multiple data points (CPU, memory, uptime) to identify root causes
Document baseline metrics to detect performance degradation over time
anti_patterns: Ignoring minor health warnings before they become major issues
Focusing only on device uptime without checking performance metrics
Making changes without first documenting the current state for reference

faq.question: What UniFi devices are supported?
faq.answer: Any UniFi device visible to the UniFi Controller including access points, switches, gateways, and USG devices.

faq.question: How frequently can I check health status?
faq.answer: There are no hard limits, but excessive queries may impact controller performance. Use batch queries when possible.

faq.question: Does this skill integrate with existing monitoring tools?
faq.answer: This skill queries UniFi data through the MCP interface. Integration with other tools depends on your MCP server setup.

faq.question: Is my network data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: All data remains within your infrastructure. The skill only queries your local UniFi Controller through the MCP server.

faq.question: Why are some devices not showing in the results?
faq.answer: Devices must be adopted by the UniFi Controller and have completed initial provisioning to appear in monitoring results.

faq.question: How is this different from the UniFi Controller interface?
faq.answer: This skill provides AI-powered querying and natural language summaries. The controller interface offers more granular configuration options.
